channel.title: Comments on: SQL Server Extracting Data (again)
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: fortboise
item.dc:creator: fortboise
item.description:
"...if you wanted to remove certain punctuation characters, but leave everything else, you could use..." pattern has the same issue as Andrei noted. The negated regexp only adnits one negation, of whatever follows.
‚Äò%[^.,-]%‚Äô is "any character other than dot, comma, and dash."
item.content:encoded:
“…if you wanted to remove certain punctuation characters, but leave everything else, you could use…” pattern has the same issue as Andrei noted. The negated regexp only adnits one negation, of whatever follows.

‚Äò%[^.,-]%‚Äô is “any character other than dot, comma, and dash.”

item.title: By: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.dc:creator: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.content:encoded:
Andrei,

Thank you for the comment. I have modified the blog to include your corrections.

item.title: By: Andrei
item.dc:creator: Andrei
item.content:encoded:
I beleive that correct filter for RemoveNonAlphaNumericCharacters would be ^a-z0-9 and not ^a-z^0-9

I was going to provide a proof for a previous comment of mine, but the site’s engine won’t allows it, saying it looks like spam üôÅ So I didnt üôÇ

item.title: By: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.dc:creator: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.description: That function looks similar, with a slight difference. My function does not loop through all the characters in the string. It uses PatIndex to quickly find the first character in the string that does not meet the criteria. Basically, my code will have less iterations for the loop, which should give better performance if there is a relatively small percentage of characters that need to be removed.
item.content:encoded: That function looks similar, with a slight difference. My function does not loop through all the characters in the string. It uses PatIndex to quickly find the first character in the string that does not meet the criteria. Basically, my code will have less iterations for the loop, which should give better performance if there is a relatively small percentage of characters that need to be removed.

item.title: By: Haley
item.dc:creator: Haley
item.description: Is there a way to do this in Access? Changed jobs and went from SQL server to Access. Working on getting sql server here, but in the meantime I would like to create an address matchkey in access where I extract numbers only, then letters without vowels only and put them back together.
item.content:encoded: Is there a way to do this in Access? Changed jobs and went from SQL server to Access. Working on getting sql server here, but in the meantime I would like to create an address matchkey in access where I extract numbers only, then letters without vowels only and put them back together.
